column3: People think celebrities don't have to worry about human things like sickness and death and rent. It's like you've traveled to this Land of Celebrity, this other country.
Americans have an abiding belief in their ability to control reality by purely material means... airline insurance replaces the fear of death with the comforting prospect of cash.
Death is someone you see very clearly with eyes in the center of your heart: eyes that see not by reacting to light, but by reacting to a kind of a chill from within the marrow of your own life.

Love never dies a natural death. It dies because we don't know how to replenish its source. It dies of blindness and errors and betrayals. It dies of illness and wounds; it dies of weariness, of witherings, of tarnishings.

That nature does not care, one way or the other, is the true abyss. That only man cares, in his finitude facing nothing but death, alone with his contingency and the objective meaninglessness of his projecting meanings, is a truly unprecedented situation.
Windmills are going to be the death of Scotland and even England if they don't do something about them. They are ruining the countryside.
I am one who believes that one of the greatest dangers of advertising is not that of misleading people, but that of boring them to death.
Despise not death, but welcome it, for nature wills it like all else.
Any business today that embraces the status quo as an operating principle is going to be on a death march.
Death comes to all, but great achievements build a monument which shall endure until the sun grows cold.
We cannot banish dangers, but we can banish fears. We must not demean life by standing in awe of death.
I hope it is true that a man can die and yet not only live in others but give them life, and not only life, but that great consciousness of life.
Always read something that will make you look good if you die in the middle of it.
A dying man needs to die, as a sleepy man needs to sleep, and there comes a time when it is wrong, as well as useless, to resist.
Death borders upon our birth, and our cradle stands in the grave.
Call no man happy before he dies, he is at best but fortunate.
Death is not more certainly a separation of our souls from our bodies than the Christian life is a separation of our souls from worldly tempers, vain indulgences, and unnecessary cares.
No one else can take risks for us, or face our losses on our behalf, or give us self-esteem. No one can spare us from life's slings and arrows, and when death comes, we meet it alone.
If nothing else, there's comfort in recognising that no matter how much we fail and sin, death will limit our suffering.

I have come to regard November as the older, harder man's October. I appreciate the early darkness and cooler temperatures. It puts my mind in a different place than October. It is a month for a quieter, slightly more subdued celebration of summer's death as winter tightens its grip.
The death of democracy is not likely to be an assassination from ambush. It will be a slow extinction from apathy, indifference, and undernourishment.
My objection to the death penalty is based on the idea that this is a democracy, and in a democracy the government is me, and if the government kills somebody then I'm killing somebody.

There is no life to be found in violence. Every act of violence brings us closer to death. Whether it's the mundane violence we do to our bodies by overeating toxic food or drink or the extreme violence of child abuse, domestic warfare, life-threatening poverty, addiction, or state terrorism.
I'm possibly a very morbid person but I think about death a lot.

Religion provides the only story that is fundamentally consoling in the face of the worst possible experiences - the death of a parent, for instance. In fact, many religions take away the problem entirely, because their adherents ostensibly believe that they're going to be reunited with everyone they love, and death is an illusion.
There's no tragedy in life like the death of a child. Things never get back to the way they were.
